Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1438052/1437275

This project will use theory, numerical simulation, and experiments to study the motion that is induced by instabilities in stratified liquid systems. For example, when fresh water from a river enters the ocean, concentration gradients of sediment and salt form simultaneously. Under certain conditions that can be predicted theoretically, the presence of these gradients leads to an unstable situation that induces convective motion of the sediment-laden water. Preliminary results show that this motion strongly affects the settling velocity and transport of the sediment. This project will develop a framework for analyzing motions induced by such instabilities in a variety of situations pertaining to river estuaries. However, the framework will be more broadly applicable to problems in environmental, geophysical, astrophysical, and engineering flows.

This collaborative project will use theoretical, computational, and experimental tools to explore the linear and nonlinear dynamics of double diffusive sedimentation under a wide range of conditions. Linear stability theory, direct numerical simulation, and laboratory experiments will be conducted for four basic configurations: a) a layer of sediment-laden fresh water above saline water; b) a layer of sediment-laden fresh water below saline water; c) linear concentration gradients with sediment being unstably stratified; d) linear concentration gradients with sediment being stably stratified. Effects of shear flow in the water, which is appropriate for river estuaries, will be included. The research will address a range of interesting phenomena observed in these systems including fingering instabilities, horizontal intrusions, and staircases formed in particulate systems. The proposed research will identify dominant instability mechanisms in various parameter regimes, and will provide quantitative scaling laws for double diffusive sedimentation in each case.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the dynamics of fluids interacting with a field of "particles", modeled as a continuum. This could represent droplets in a cloud, or marine snow, or sediments from a river estuary, for instance. The particles interact with the fluid through drag, and as a result, contribute to its buoyancy. We investigated scenarios in which the particles are stably stratified (lying closer to the bottom of the fluid) and scenarios where they are unstably stratified (lying near the surface of the fluid). In all cases, and contrary to expectations, we found that this two-fluid interaction could lead to the development of instabilities, especially when the particles inertia is taken into account. We developed a new numerical code to study the problem, and applied it to various scenarios. 

In a scenario where the particles are stably stratified, we discovered the existence of a new instability that only arises due to particle inertia, from the delay in the response of the fluid to fluid motion. This delay effectively amplifies internal waves in the system, slowly with time. While this was discovered purely mathematically, we are currently investigating whether this effect is significant on Earth or in astrophysical systems.

In another scenario, where particles are unstably stratified, but lie in a fluid with a stable temperature stratification, the system undergoes sedimentary fingering convection, which can also lead to the formation of "staircases" in the particle and temperature stratification. We explained the formation of such staircases using a simple mathematical model. These staircases are important because they largely increase the intensity of vertical transport in the fluid. 

In a third scenario, where particles are even more unstably stratified, we discovered and discuss the existence of two regimes in which the particle concentration either always decreases with time as a result of mixing, or, can increase with time as a result of a well-known effect called inertial concentration. 

The effect of such instabilities on unstable particle distributions is to change the sedimentation rate of the particles, and the local particle concentration. This likely has significant impact on models of sedimentation, which are used for instance to predict where sediments from river outflows are deposited in the ocean (which is used in oil-field identification), or in cloud physics, to predict the rate at which small droplets fall and condense into larger drops.
